title: To create a variable in Python, all you need to do is specify the variable name, and then assign a value to it.

inline_content.Text: To create a variable in Python, all you need to do is specify the variable name, and then assign a value to it.

title: Python uses
c

to assign values to variables. There’s no need to declare a variable in advance (or to assign a data type to it), assigning a value to a variable itself declares and initializes the variable with that value. There’s no way to declare a variable without assigning it an initial value.

inline_content.Text: to assign values to variables. There’s no need to declare a variable in advance (or to assign a data type to it), assigning a value to a variable itself declares and initializes the variable with that value. There’s no way to declare a variable without assigning it an initial value.

title:
# Integer
a = 2
print(a)
# Output: 2

# Integer    
b = 9223372036854775807
print(b)
# Output: 9223372036854775807

# Floating point
pi = 3.14
print(pi)
# Output: 3.14

# String
c = 'A'
print(c)
# Output: A

# String    
name = 'John Doe'
print(name)
# Output: John Doe

# Boolean    
q = True
print(q)
# Output: True

# Empty value or null data type
x = None
print(x)
# Output: None

content_resolved.code:
# Integer
a = 2
print(a)
# Output: 2

# Integer    
b = 9223372036854775807
print(b)
# Output: 9223372036854775807

# Floating point
pi = 3.14
print(pi)
# Output: 3.14

# String
c = 'A'
print(c)
# Output: A

# String    
name = 'John Doe'
print(name)
# Output: John Doe

# Boolean    
q = True
print(q)
# Output: True

# Empty value or null data type
x = None
print(x)
# Output: None

title: Variable assignment works from left to right. So the following will give you an syntax error.

inline_content.Text: Variable assignment works from left to right. So the following will give you an syntax error.

title:
0 = x
=> Output: SyntaxError: can't assign to literal

content_resolved.code:
0 = x
=> Output: SyntaxError: can't assign to literal

title: You can not use python’s keywords as a valid variable name. You can see the list of keyword by:

inline_content.Text: You can not use python’s keywords as a valid variable name. You can see the list of keyword by:

title: Variables names must start with a letter or an underscore.

x  = True   # valid
_y = True   # valid

9x = False  # starts with numeral 
=> SyntaxError: invalid syntax   

$y = False #  starts with symbol 
=> SyntaxError: invalid syntax

content_resolved.code:
x  = True   # valid
_y = True   # valid

9x = False  # starts with numeral 
=> SyntaxError: invalid syntax   

$y = False #  starts with symbol 
=> SyntaxError: invalid syntax

inline_content.Text: Variables names must start with a letter or an underscore.

title: The remainder of your variable name may consist of letters, numbers and underscores.

inline_content.Text: The remainder of your variable name may consist of letters, numbers and underscores.

title:
x = 9  
y = X*5   
=>NameError: name 'X' is not defined

content_resolved.code:
x = 9  
y = X*5   
=>NameError: name 'X' is not defined

title: Even though there’s no need to specify a data type when declaring a variable in Python, while allocating the necessary area in memory for the variable, the Python interpreter automatically picks the most suitable
built-in type
a
http://stackoverflow.com/documentation/python/193/introduction-to-python/2926/datatypes#t=201610091728094101649
for it:

inline_content.Text: Even though there’s no need to specify a data type when declaring a variable in Python, while allocating the necessary area in memory for the variable, the Python interpreter automatically picks the most suitable

title:
a = 2
print(type(a))
# Output: <type 'int'>

b = 9223372036854775807
print(type(b))
# Output: <type 'int'>

pi = 3.14
print(type(pi))
# Output: <type 'float'>

c = 'A'
print(type(c))
# Output: <type 'str'>

name = 'John Doe'
print(type(name))
# Output: <type 'str'>

q = True
print(type(q))
# Output: <type 'bool'>

x = None
print(type(x))
# Output: <type 'NoneType'>

content_resolved.code:
a = 2
print(type(a))
# Output: <type 'int'>

b = 9223372036854775807
print(type(b))
# Output: <type 'int'>

pi = 3.14
print(type(pi))
# Output: <type 'float'>

c = 'A'
print(type(c))
# Output: <type 'str'>

name = 'John Doe'
print(type(name))
# Output: <type 'str'>

q = True
print(type(q))
# Output: <type 'bool'>

x = None
print(type(x))
# Output: <type 'NoneType'>

title: Now you know the basics of assignment, let’s get this subtlety about assignment in python out of the way.

inline_content.Text: Now you know the basics of assignment, let’s get this subtlety about assignment in python out of the way.

title: You can assign multiple values to multiple variables in one line. Note that there must be the same number of arguments on the right and left sides of the
c
operator:

inline_content.Text: You can assign multiple values to multiple variables in one line. Note that there must be the same number of arguments on the right and left sides of the

title:
a, b, c = 1, 2, 3
print(a, b, c)
# Output: 1 2 3

content_resolved.code:
a, b, c = 1, 2, 3
print(a, b, c)
# Output: 1 2 3

title:

=> Traceback (most recent call last):

title: The error in last example can be obviated by assigning remaining values to equal number of arbitrary variables. This dummy variable can have any name, but it is conventional to use the underscore (
c
) for assigning unwanted values:

inline_content.Text: The error in last example can be obviated by assigning remaining values to equal number of arbitrary variables. This dummy variable can have any name, but it is conventional to use the underscore (

title: Note that the number of _ and number of remaining values must be equal. Otherwise ‘too many values to unpack error’ is thrown as above:

inline_content.Text: Note that the number of _ and number of remaining values must be equal. Otherwise ‘too many values to unpack error’ is thrown as above:

title:
a, b, _ = 1,2,3,4
=>Traceback (most recent call last):
=>File "name.py", line N, in <module>
=>a, b, _ = 1,2,3,4
=>ValueError: too many values to unpack (expected 3)

content_resolved.code:
a, b, _ = 1,2,3,4
=>Traceback (most recent call last):
=>File "name.py", line N, in <module>
=>a, b, _ = 1,2,3,4
=>ValueError: too many values to unpack (expected 3)

title: You can also assign a single value to several variables simultaneously.

inline_content.Text: You can also assign a single value to several variables simultaneously.

title:
a = b = c = 1
print(a, b, c)
# Output: 1 1 1

content_resolved.code:
a = b = c = 1
print(a, b, c)
# Output: 1 1 1

title: When using such cascading assignment, it is important to note that all three variables
a
c
b
c
and
c
c
refer to the
same object
i
in memory, an
int
c
object with the value of 1. In other words,
a
c
b
c
and
c
c
are three different names given to the same int object. Assigning a different object to one of them afterwards doesn’t change the others, just as expected:

inline_content.Text: When using such cascading assignment, it is important to note that all three variables
object with the value of 1. In other words,
are three different names given to the same int object. Assigning a different object to one of them afterwards doesn’t change the others, just as expected:

title:
a = b = c = 1    # all three names a, b and c refer to same int object with value 1
print(a, b, c)
# Output: 1 1 1
b = 2            # b now refers to another int object, one with a value of 2
print(a, b, c)
# Output: 1 2 1  # so output is as expected.

content_resolved.code:
a = b = c = 1    # all three names a, b and c refer to same int object with value 1
print(a, b, c)
# Output: 1 1 1
b = 2            # b now refers to another int object, one with a value of 2
print(a, b, c)
# Output: 1 2 1  # so output is as expected.

title:
x = y = [7, 8, 9]   # x and y refer to the same list object just created, [7, 8, 9]
x = [13, 8, 9]      # x now refers to a different list object just created, [13, 8, 9]
print(y)            # y still refers to the list it was first assigned
# Output: [7, 8, 9]

content_resolved.code:
x = y = [7, 8, 9]   # x and y refer to the same list object just created, [7, 8, 9]
x = [13, 8, 9]      # x now refers to a different list object just created, [13, 8, 9]
print(y)            # y still refers to the list it was first assigned
# Output: [7, 8, 9]

title: So far so good. Things are a bit different when it comes to
modifying
i
the object (in contrast to
assigning
i
the name to a different object, which we did above) when the cascading assignment is used for mutable types. Take a look below, and you will see it first hand:

inline_content.Text: So far so good. Things are a bit different when it comes to
the name to a different object, which we did above) when the cascading assignment is used for mutable types. Take a look below, and you will see it first hand:

title:
x = y = [7, 8, 9]     # x and y are two different names for the same list object just created, [7, 8, 9]
x[0] = 13             # we are updating the value of the list [7, 8, 9] through one of its names, x in this case
print(y)              # printing the value of the list using its other name
# Output: [13, 8, 9]  # hence, naturally the change is reflected

content_resolved.code:
x = y = [7, 8, 9]     # x and y are two different names for the same list object just created, [7, 8, 9]
x[0] = 13             # we are updating the value of the list [7, 8, 9] through one of its names, x in this case
print(y)              # printing the value of the list using its other name
# Output: [13, 8, 9]  # hence, naturally the change is reflected

title: Nested lists are also valid in python. This means that a list can contain another list as an element.

inline_content.Text: Nested lists are also valid in python. This means that a list can contain another list as an element.

title:
x = [1, 2, [3, 4, 5], 6, 7] # this is nested list
print x[2]
# Output: [3, 4, 5]
print x[2][1]
# Output: 4

content_resolved.code:
x = [1, 2, [3, 4, 5], 6, 7] # this is nested list
print x[2]
# Output: [3, 4, 5]
print x[2][1]
# Output: 4

title: Lastly, variables in Python do not have to stay the same type as which they were first defined – you can simply use
c
to assign a new value to a variable, even if that value is of a different type.

inline_content.Text: Lastly, variables in Python do not have to stay the same type as which they were first defined – you can simply use
to assign a new value to a variable, even if that value is of a different type.

title:
a = 2 
print(a)
# Output: 2

a = "New value"
print(a)
# Output: New value

content_resolved.code:
a = 2 
print(a)
# Output: 2

a = "New value"
print(a)
# Output: New value

c
, then you change your mind and decide to give the name

c
to a

object, having value ‘New value’. Simple, right?
